title: Keratosis Pilaris: What It Is and How to Treat It

sections.heading: What Is Keratosis Pilaris?
content: Keratosis pilaris (KP) is a very common benign skin condition characterized by numerous small red or brown bumps involving the hair follicle. You may have even heard of this before, as it’s often referred to as “strawberry skin” or “chicken skin.” These bumps are rough in texture and sometimes associated with scaling.

They appear most often on the upper arms and thighs but may also be found on the cheeks and buttocks. A key feature of KP is that it tends to be symmetric, occurring on both sides of the body simultaneously. Though these bumps typically don’t cause symptoms, some people may find them irritating, itchy, or just plain bothersome to look at.
KP is most prevalent in children, adolescents, and young adults. Because it is so common, many consider KP a variant of normal skin.

KP is caused by the plugging of hair follicles with keratin, a protein important for the structure and function of your skin, hair, and nails. KP has been associated with filaggrin gene mutations, the same gene mutations found in people with atopic dermatitis (also known as eczema). In fact, KP affects more than 40% of people with eczema.

content: If you have low levels of functioning filaggrin, you may also have problems with your skin being able to retain moisture. It’s also not surprising that KP gets worse with cool weather, low humidity, and dry skin. In addition, there’s also a genetic component to KP. Members of the same family often exhibit identical skin problems. In this case, KP is thought to be passed on via an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

While KP cannot be cured, rest assured that treatment is not required for this harmless condition. However, if you are looking for ways to treat your KP, there are options available that may help to improve the appearance of your skin. It’s important to note that most cases do get better with time, especially if you have it on your face. This area tends to get better during puberty.

sections.heading: Moisturize.
content: For those interested in treatment, start with the basics: moisturizing. Don’t underestimate the power of maintaining hydrated, well-moisturized skin when it comes to treating this chronic (and often very stubborn) condition. Using gentle cleansers and moisturizing creams can help to prevent excessive dryness that predisposes you to the development or worsening of KP.

sections.heading: Exfoliate.
content: Exfoliants may also be used to make the skin feel smoother. Urea cream and creams containing alpha and beta hydroxy acids (such as lactic acid, glycolic acid, and salicylic acid) are examples of keratolytic agents that help to gently break down rough, scaly skin. Prescription-strength topical retinoids such as tretinoin or tazarotene are also frequently used and may provide benefit.

These products are best used on an ongoing, maintenance basis to prevent your bumps from recurring. In people with sensitive skin or eczema, these ingredients might cause some irritation, so use them slowly and cautiously. For those mostly bothered by the red appearance of the bumps, seeking treatment with a vascular laser may improve the redness, though results in studies are mixed and do not lead to reliable improvement in everyone.
Rarely, KP may cause itching and discomfort; in these cases, topical steroid creams such as hydrocortisone may be used.

Get medical help. If you don’t get any results from over-the-counter solutions, it might be time to seek expert consultation with a dermatologist. You can discuss other lifestyle changes or prescription medications to further improve your skin’s appearance and alleviate symptoms.

content: Keep in mind that this is ultimately a benign chronic condition with a genetic basis that gets better with age. There are still things you could be doing to minimize the appearance of your KP. If you have KP, let this be your mantra: exfoliate, moisturize, and repeat!
